title: Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

last_post.content:
I am going to keep posting about this until we get to 100,000 signatures.

You are now getting bored of seeing these posts, please don't give up, we can do this.

As I write there are 88,402 signatures. The linear trend line of signatures from Tuesday 31 January gives an equation of
y = 925.5x + 82681.
That means the date for hitting 100,000 votes has drifted out by two more days to Friday 17 February. I know we can do better than this. The last we thing we want is the petition to remove LGBT content from the curriculum to be debated and our opinion not to be heard.

Please sign if you are in the UK and please boost if you are not.

May I take this opportunity to thank each and everyone of the 1,180 people that have boosted this post so far. ❤️ 💖

Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/631529

#TransRightsAreHumanrRghts #Trans

title: Sam Bankman-Fried is not a child

last_post.content:
Only reading headlines and news stories, you would be forgiven if up until now you had thought SBF was a teenager still driving around on a learner’s permit, who picked up crypto trading to avoid high school summer jobs that might force him to go outside.

https://newsletter.mollywhite.net/p/sam-bankman-fried-is-not-a-child

title: A New Drug Switched Off My Appetite. What’s Left?

last_post.content:
In my most recent column for WIRED I describe my experience with Mounjaro, a new drug for type 2 diabetics that deeply manipulates satiety, with a side effect of radical weight loss.

Fat is a vast subject involving economics, agriculture, race, gender, sexuality, cultural norms, psychology, biology, even climate. In contrast I'm relating an individual, fragmentary experience, in a state of confusion, at a moment of vulnerability. I'm sure it will go great.

https://www.wired.com/story/new-drug-switched-off-appetite-mounjaro/

Right on, about Big Tech.

There's an interesting new paper in the journal Ecological Economics. The title is:

"Assessing US consumers' carbon footprints reveals outsized impact of top 1%"
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0921800922003597

This is from the abstract --

Unsustainable environmental degradation and extreme economic inequality are two of humanity's most pressing challenges. They are intimately linked. Climate-altering greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are disproportionately driven by consumption among wealthy and socially privileged groups, yet poorer and socially marginalized peoples face disproportionate climate harms.
________________________

What really grabbed me, however, was the chart below, created by Andrew Fanning using data contained in the paper. It clearly illustrates the massive scale of carbon inequality in our modern society.

#Inequality #GreenhouseGases #Emissions #ClimateCrisis #ClimateJustice

title: The Cement Mixer Space Capsule of Winganon

last_post.content:
A cement truck crashed near Winganon, Oklahoma in the 1950s and the mixer was too heavy to move. It’s still there; locals have painted it to look like an abandoned NASA
capsule.

title: Top climate scientists are sceptical that nations will rein in global warming

last_post.content:
When leading climate scientists are asked anonymously or off-the-record what they actually expect we will have to endure in the decades ahead, you'll find they are not very optimistic.

In 2021, the journal Nature conducted an anonymous survey of IPCC authors and received responses from 92 scientists. Their answers suggest strong skepticism that governments will significantly slow the pace of global heating, despite all those fancy promises we've heard ("blah-blah-blah").

Six in ten of the survey respondents expect the world to warm by at least 3°C by the end of the century. Some think 4°C or even 5°C is where we're headed. Fewer than 5% of these scientists believe we will stay under 1.5°C, which is the optimistic — and totally unrealistic — outcome that politicians and the major media want you to swallow.

#ClimateCrisis

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-02990-w

In one Walpurgis Night, the postman of Wittmar waited for his usual delivery, but it had not arrived. Thus, he went out on the road to see if it was coming.

However, there was a crossroads in front of the post station. As soon as he had stepped on it, his nose was twisted around until it was on the back of his head.

He died out of fright.

#Germany #folktale #folklore
https://viewer.rsl.ru/ru/rsl01004457405?page=110&rotate=0&theme=white

title: Open Review of the Second Half of “After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory”

last_post.content:
Starting on revisions to respond to peer reviews of my forthcoming book, After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory. For background on the book, you can read the full drafts of it here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/07/open-review-of-the-second-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/ and here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/01/open-review-of-the-first-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/

I am planning to add some additional targeted positive examples of cultural memory work/projects/initiatives that model centering an ethic of care, a maintenance mindset, and a focus on repair.

title: Is cycling safe? In many cases, the answer is no.

last_post.content:
Very big implications to finding (2 studies, in London & Paris) that woman cyclists get killed more than men because they wait for signal to start across intersection.
This is surely true for pedestrians too, since geometry is the same.
Implies that using marked crosswalk & obeying signal is often more dangerous than violating law. 1/2
https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2023/01/is-cycling-safe-in-many-cases-the-answer-is-no/
https://www.lemonde.fr/les-decodeurs/article/2023/02/04/que-peut-on-dire-de-la-hausse-inquietante-des-morts-de-cyclistes_6160557_4355770.html

title: Journalistic Lessons for the Algorithmic Age – The Markup

last_post.content: I will always remember the crazy early days working with @Julia get @themarkup off the ground. I learned so much from our time working together. Proud to see the newsroom on solid ground reflecting the vision Julia defined and fought to make real. https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/02/04/journalistic-lessons-for-the-algorithmic-age

With so many places having done layoffs lately, I wanted to mention the US Digital Service is hiring. It's a wild place to work, but also you get to work on legitimately meaningful projects that affect a lot of people (in 2022, we made it easier for transgender ppl to get passports, helped low-income families buy food, and I got to help identify disadvantage communities for environmental funding). I'm happy to talk about USDS if you're on the fence. http://ow.ly/LpqJ50LVnPV #fedihire #fedijobs
